page.title: 19CHANGING TIMES IN WOODCOTE
page.content: The Village Hall was donated to Woodcote by Mr Algernon Borthwick of Woodcote House (now the Oratory School) as a recreation centre for the men who returned after the first world war and for village facilities. Billiards,card games and darts were played. The Village Hall was also used by the Women's Institute and for social evenings,whist drives and dances. The highlight of the week was the filmshow on Tuesday night. When the hall was first built the rec. was covered in prickly gorse. It was common land given to the village under the enclosure act. It was cleared so that cricket and football could be played there. The school used in the 1920s still stands on the Langtree site. There were forty children aged 5 to 14 years.
